normalised: **My Heart's a Flutter (and not in a good way!)**

unnormalised: Okay, folks, let's talk cardiology. Not because I suddenly became a heart surgeon (though, imagine the drama!), but because my own ticker has been acting up. And by acting up, I mean staging a full-blown Bollywood dance number whenever I climb the stairs. Forget "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge," my heart's more like "Dil Dhadakne Do" – constantly threatening to run off and join a cruise ship.

unnormalised: It all started subtly. A bit of breathlessness after a particularly vigorous chai-drinking session. A mild chest pain that I initially dismissed as indigestion from my mother-in-law’s notoriously spicy biryani. But then came the palpitations. Not the cute, "oh, he's so dreamy" kind. More like the "is this what a heart attack feels like?" kind. So, naturally, I googled my symptoms. Bad move. Dr. Google diagnosed me with everything from a mild arrhythmia to impending doom. Thanks, Doc!

More like the "is this what a heart attack feels like?" kind. So, naturally, I googled my symptoms. Bad move. Doctor Google diagnosed me with everything from a mild arrhythmia to impending doom. Thanks, Doc!

unnormalised: So, I finally bit the bullet and visited a real doctor. Dr. Sharma, a cardiologist at Max Hospital, bless her soul, didn't laugh when I described my self-diagnosis. She did, however, raise an eyebrow at my insistence that my heart was trying to learn the bhangra. After a barrage of tests (EKG, ECG, stress test – the works!), she declared that I was, in fact, not dying. Just…slightly out of shape. Apparently, my diet of samosas and constant worry about IPL scores wasn’t doing me any favors.

She did, however, raise an eyebrow at my insistence that my heart was trying to learn the bhangra. After a barrage of tests (E-K-G, E-C-G, stress test – the works!), she declared that I was, in fact, not dying. Just…slightly out of shape. Apparently, my diet of samosas and constant worry about I-P-L scores wasn’t doing me any favors.

unnormalised: Turns out, I have a minor heart murmur. "Insignificant," Dr. Sharma assured me. "But you should still take it easy." Easy? Me? The guy who tries to outrun auto-rickshaws to save Rs. 10? The man who considers walking to the fridge a workout? This was going to be a challenge.

unnormalised: She prescribed some meds – a low dose beta-blocker (25mg, if you must know) to slow down my heart rate and reduce the palpitations. She also recommended some lifestyle changes. Exercise? Oh god, I hate this. I was told to swap my 3 cups of chai a day for green tea (heresy!), and cut down on the fried food. Basically, she wanted me to live like a saint. Or at least, someone who doesn't regularly indulge in a plate of golgappas.

unnormalised: The worst part? She said I needed to exercise. "30 mins of brisk walking 5 times a week," she chirped. Brisk walking? In Mumbai humidity? I’d rather wrestle a cobra. But fine, for the sake of my unruly heart, I'll try. I'm picturing myself looking like Milind Soman by next month. Maybe. More likely, I'll be slumped on a bench, sweating profusely and contemplating the existential dread of cardio.

unnormalised: So here I am, folks. A reluctant cardiology patient, armed with medication and a newfound appreciation for green tea. I am not sure how much longer I can withstand the change, but for now, I'm following Dr. Sharma's orders. I'm taking my meds, I'm walking (slowly, very slowly), and I'm trying to resist the siren call of the vada pav. Wish me luck – my heart (and my taste buds) are going to need it.
